results.title: Retirement income perils
results.creator_credit: Sally Wiadrowski and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: In this “4 Corners” special, reporter Chris Masters investigates an area which is causing plenty of grey hairs - Retirement Investment Planning - RIP. This is an overview of the efficacy of superannuation savings and how it will or will not allow people to live comfortably after retirement.

results.title: Research by rockets
results.creator_credit: Arnold Frutkin, Stanley Ruttenberg, Lothar Wolff and National Academy of Sciences (U.S.)
results.brief_description: The use of rockets as tools for scientific research in the upper atmosphere. How rockets are the means of placing scientific instruments into the high atmosphere in order to measure space phenomena. Includes footage of experimental rocket flights in the 1920’s.

results.title: Requiem for a dream [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Darren Aronofsky, Eric Watson, Artisan Entertainment and Thousand Words Productions
results.brief_description: Although the plot of “Requiem for a dream” revolves around four very human humans, the hero of the film is undoubtedly addiction. Addiction to food, to heroin, to diet pills, and that most everyday habit, to television. If film noir attacked The American Dream, then Darren Aronofsky’s follow-up to “Pi” sees that dream kidnapped, tortured and burned. This is exacted in the junkie lifestyle of Harry and his friends, as well as the loneliness of his mother, portrayed by Ellen Burstyn, whose performance makes “Requiem for a dream” one of the best movies of 2001. A victim to heroin chic but also, eventually, a critic, this film is aimed at a young audience but takes the unusual step of actually having something to say. The screenplay was written by Aronofsky and Hubert Selby Jnr (‘Last Exit To Brooklyn’), based on the latter’s novel. It also features one of the most progressive film soundtracks of recent years, written and performed by Clint Mansell and the Kronos Quartet.

results.title: Requiem by Andrew Lloyd Webber
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Burton, Ian Squires, BBC-TV and The Really Useful Group
results.brief_description: Filmed on location at the St Thomas Church, New York, on Sunday February 24th 1985, the world premiere of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Requiem” was performed to an enthusiastic and receptive audience. The wonderful voices of Placido Domingo (tenor), Sarah Brightman (soprano) and Paul Miles-Kingston (treble) supported by the Winchester Cathedral Choir (directed by Martin Neary), The St Thomas Choir (directed by Gerre Hancock) and the Orchestra of St Luke’s conducted by Lorin Maazel give depth and quality to Webber’s original composition.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Humphrey Burton, Ian Squires, BBC-TV and The Really Useful Group

results.title: The Milky way
results.creator_credit: ACI Films and United World Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
This film presents a scientist’s conception of how stars were formed. It includes a brief explanation of the Milky Way and shows the telescopes used to study stars, light and radio waves. Suitable for lower secondary level.

group_siblings.title: Over the hill to the moon

results.title: Rendezvous
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
This program examines the application of necessary physical laws to bring two orbiting space craft to a meeting in space. “Rendezvous” illustrates accomplishing a complete rendezvous manoeuvre when two spacecraft are in different orbits and on different planes.

results.title: Over the hill to the moon
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
How does a spacecraft overcome the conflicting gravity pulls when travelling from earth to the moon? This program addresses this problem and also dramatises an entire lunar flight through the use of animation and exciting live footage.

results.title: Energy in orbit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
This program uses animated dramatisation to examine the characteristics of potential and kinetic energy, and the ways in which these forces affect a satellite’s orbit.

results.title: Principles of orbit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
How do the laws of inertia and universal gravitation govern the flight of an orbiting satellite? This program investigates the question by demonstrating the behaviour of a satellite, both in circular and elliptical orbit.
